questions.text: Which one of the following drugs does not crosses BBB, but potentiates the activity of Dopamine in the brain?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Carbidopa Carbidopa and benserazide are peripheral dopa decarboxylase inhibitors and do not penetrate the blood-brain barrier. They potentiate the activity of dopamine inside the brain by inhibiting the conversion of levodopa to dopamine in the periphery. They do not inhibit the conversion of levodopa to dopamine in the brain.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A : Tolcapone is a COMT inhibitor that can cross BBB. Option C : Levodopa is a precursor of dopamine and can cross BBB. Option D : Selegiline is an MAO b inhibitor that can cross BBB

Table:

#MANTRA Carbidopa Carbidopa is a DOPA decarboxylase inhibitor that does not cross the blood-brain barrier When given with levodopa, the peripheral metabolism of levodopa is reduced with the following consequences: The half-life of levodopa is increased More levodopa is available for entering the brain (this reduces by about 75% the daily requirement) Gastrointestinal and cardiovascular effects of levodopa are substantially reduced. CNS adverse effects are increased Levodopa is usually given in combination with carbidopa

questions.text: A Patient on long term treatment with levodopa therapy develops dyskinetic movements and dose-related fluctuations, best adjuvant treatment for this patient is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Amantadine Amantidine is best adjuvant for dyskinetic movements and dose-related fluctuations in patients on long term treatment with levodopa Amantadine decreases dyskinetic movements Amantadine is less efficacious than levodopa, and its benefits may be short-lived, often disappearing after only a few weeks of treatment. Nevertheless, during that time it may favorably influence the bradykinesia, rigidity, and tremor of parkinsonism. The standard dosage is 100 mg orally two or three times daily. Amantadine may also help in reducing iatrogenic dyskinesias in patients with advanced disease.

questions.text: Cholinomimetics drugs are less likely to be effective in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:

Parkinsonism

Highyeild:

Cholinomimetics drugs are effective in Alzheimer's disease Antimuscranic poisoning Myasthenia gravis note: In Parkinsonism there is excess of cholinergic and less of dopaminergic activity, so in this, anticholinergics are effective not cholinomimetics.

It is the cause of 60–70% of cases of dementia. The most common early symptom is difficulty in remembering recent events Option: B . Antimuscarinic poisoning Overdosing on antimuscarinics may lead to anticholinergic syndrome , which can present with dry mouth, flushed skin, tachycardia, confusion, and agitation. It may also lead to anticholinergic delirium, hallucinations, and psychomotor symptoms. Option: C. Myasthenia gravis (MG) is a long-term neuromuscular junction disease that leads to varying degrees of skeletal muscle weakness.
